question: My husband and I were recently rear ended at a high rate of speed.  We were both transported via ambulance to the hospital and my husband complained that his right eye felt "weird".  The issue was not addressed in the ER and my husband just let it go.  He finally admitted that his vision had been blurry since the accident.  Our family physician recommended seeing an opthamologist.  We did not know one so we saw our optometrist.  My husband sees the eye doctor at least every two years and has never had a problem with pressures or any other issues during these visits.  His last exam was 17/17 pressures with his vision corrected to 20/20 with glasses.  Now everyone saying that there is no way the accident had anything to do with his now blurry vision and pressure of 50 in his right eye.  (Which we decreased with drops in less than 24 hours)  He has always had astigmatism that has never caused a problem.  He does not have diabetes, high blood pressure.  He does have Idiopathic Epilepsy that is controlled with 600 mg tegretol daily.  He has high cholesterol also treated with  Lipitor 40mg a day.     I cannot believe that he now has sudden glaucoma when his last appointment with the 17/17 reading was in February of this year.   I have done some research and what I find says that you can get high pressure readings after a trauma.  Adreneline rush that causes the pupil to dilate could cause trauma to the eye.  I just want to know if anyone agrees with me.  My husband still has blurred vision, may have to have surgery or may have lost vision in that eye.  We are going to sue the person who rear ended us and I can't help but believe that these doctors just don't want to get involved.  Thanks for any help you can give me.
title: Blurred vision after rear end collision
